question:
Make correct statements by filling in the symbols $\subset$ or $\not\subset$ in the blank spaces:
(i) $\{5, 6, 7\} \dots \{1, 5, 6, 7, 8\}$
(ii) $\{p, q, r\} \dots \{q, r, s\}$
(iii) $\{x : x \text{ is a square in the plane}\} \dots \{x : x \text{ is a rectangle in the same plane}\}$
(iv) $\{x : x \text{ is a triangle in the plane}\} \dots \{x : x \text{ is a right triangle in the plane}\}$
(v) $\{x : x \text{ is a natural number}\} \dots \{x : x \text{ is a whole number}\}$
(vi) $\{x : x \text{ is a rhombus}\} \dots \{x : x \text{ is a parallelogram}\}$
(vii) $\{x : x \text{ is an integer}\} \dots \{x : x \text{ is a rational number}\}$
solutionSteps: (i) All elements {5, 6, 7} are in the second set. Symbol: $\subset$
(ii) Element 'p' is not in the second set. Symbol: $\not\subset$
(iii) Every square is a rectangle. Symbol: $\subset$
(iv) The set of all triangles includes acute, obtuse, etc., not just right triangles. Symbol: $\not\subset$
(v) Natural numbers {1, 2, ...} are contained in Whole numbers {0, 1, 2, ...}. Symbol: $\subset$
(vi) Every rhombus is a parallelogram. Symbol: $\subset$
(vii) Every integer can be written as p/q (e.g., 5/1), so it is a rational number. Symbol: $\subset$

question:
Examine whether the following statements are true or false:
(i) $\{x, y\} \not\subset \{y, z, x\}$
(ii) $\{a, e, i\} \subset \{x : x \text{ is a vowel in the English alphabet}\}$
(iii) $\{1, 2, 3\} \subset \{2, 3, 4\}$
(iv) $\{p\} \subset \{p, q, r\}$
(v) $\{p\} \in \{p, q, r\}$
(vi) $\{x : x \text{ is a prime number less than 5}\} \subset \{x : x \text{ is a natural number less than 5}\}$
solutionSteps: (i) {x, y} is a subset of {y, z, x}. Statement says not subset. False.
(ii) a, e, i are vowels. True.
(iii) 1 is in LHS but not RHS. False.
(iv) 'p' is in RHS. True.
(v) {p} is a set, not an element of {p, q, r}. False.
(vi) LHS = {2, 3}. RHS = {1, 2, 3, 4}. {2, 3} is in RHS. True.
finalAnswer: (i) False (ii) True (iii) False (iv) True (v) False (vi) True

question:
Let $A = \{a, b, \{c, d\}, e\}$. Which of the following statements are incorrect and why?
(i) $\{c, d\} \subset A$
(ii) $\{c, d\} \in A$
(iii) $\{\{c, d\}\} \subset A$
(iv) $a \in A$
(v) $a \subset A$
(vi) $\{a, b, e\} \subset A$
(vii) $\{a, b, c\} \subset A$
(viii) $\phi \in A$
(ix) $\phi \subset A$
(x) $\{\phi\} \subset A$
solutionSteps: (i) {c, d} is an element, not a subset. Incorrect.
(ii) {c, d} is an element of A. Correct.
(iii) {{c, d}} is a subset containing the element {c, d}. Correct.
(iv) a is an element. Correct.
(v) a is an element, not a set. Incorrect.
(vi) a, b, e are elements of A. Correct.
(vii) c is not an element of A (it is inside {c, d}). Incorrect.
(viii) Phi is not an element of A. Incorrect.
(ix) Phi is a subset of every set. Correct.
(x) Phi is not an element of A, so {Phi} is not a subset. Incorrect.

question:
Write down all the subsets of the following sets:
(i) $\{x\}$
(ii) $\{1, 2\}$
(iii) $\{x, y, z\}$
(iv) $\phi$
solutionSteps: (i) Subsets: $\phi, \{x\}$
(iv) Subsets: $\phi$

question: How many elements has $P(A)$, if $A = \{1\}$?
solutionSteps: Number of elements $n(A) = 1$.
Number of elements in Power Set $n(P(A)) = 2^{n(A)} = 2^1 = 2$.

question:
Write the following as intervals:
(i) $\{x : x \in R, -2 < x \le 5\}$
(ii) $\{x : x \in R, -10 < x < -5\}$
(iii) $\{x : x \in R, 1 \le x < 8\}$
(iv) $\{x : x \in R, 4 \le x \le 9\}$
solutionSteps: (i) Open at -2, closed at 5: $(-2, 5]$
(ii) Open at both ends: $(-10, -5)$
(iii) Closed at 1, open at 8: $[1, 8)$
(iv) Closed at both ends: $[4, 9]$

question:
Write the following intervals in set-builder form:
(i) $(-5, 2)$
(ii) $[4, 10]$
(iii) $(2, 9]$
(iv) $[-15, 3)$
solutionSteps: (ii) $\{x : x \in R, 4 \le x \le 10\}$
(iii) $\{x : x \in R, 2 < x \le 9\}$

question:
What universal set(s) would you propose for each of the following:
(i) The set of squares
(ii) The set of rectangles
solutionSteps: For both sets, the universal set can be the set of all quadrilaterals or the set of all polygons in a plane.
finalAnswer: The set of all quadrilaterals or polygons.

question:
Given the sets $A = \{1, 2\}, B = \{3, 4\}$ and $C = \{1, 3, 5\}$, which of the following may be considered as universal set (s) for all the three sets A, B and C?
(i) $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$
(ii) $\phi$
(iii) $\{0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$
(iv) $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 6\}$
solutionSteps: A universal set must contain all elements from A, B, and C.
Elements required: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}.
(i) Missing 5.
(ii) Empty.
(iii) Contains {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}. Valid.
(iv) Missing 5.
